key_points: Facebook has closed the personal accounts of two NYU researchers and ended their project investigating misinformation in political ads.
The researchers, affiliated with the NYU Ad Observatory Project, claim Facebook is trying to control research that portrays the company negatively.
Facebook accuses the researchers of violating its terms of service by collecting data without authorization.
The NYU project aimed to expose flaws in Facebook's Ad Library and identify misinformation in political ads.
Laura Edelson, lead researcher, criticized Facebook's action for also affecting other researchers and journalists relying on their data.
The researchers used a web browser plug-in to gather data on how Facebook targets political ads, which Facebook claims violated user privacy.
Facebook took action after being informed the researchers were studying disinformation about the Jan. 6 Capitol attack.
Mike Clark, Facebook's product management director, emphasized the company's openness to accountable research but not at the expense of privacy and platform security.
Democratic Senators Mark Warner and Amy Klobuchar expressed concerns over Facebook's termination of the researchers' access.
Facebook defends its provision of political ad information via its Ad Library and other privacy-protected data sets to researchers.
spokespersons: Laura Edelson (Lead Researcher, NYU Cybersecurity for Democracy)
